methods.name: escape
methods.summary: Efficiently escape a string for insertion into HTML (innerHTML or attributes), replacing &, <, >, ", ', and / characters.

methods.name: pad

parameters.name: end
parameters.summary: adds padding at the end if true, otherwise pads at start

methods.summary: Pad a string to guarantee that it is at least size length by filling with the character ch at either the start or end of the string. Pads at the start, by default.
examples:
// Fill the string to length 10 with "+" characters on the right.  Yields "Dojo++++++".
string.pad("Dojo", 10, "+", true);

parameters.name: num
parameters.summary: number of times to replicate the string

methods.name: substitute

parameters.name: template
parameters.summary: a string with expressions in the form ${key} to be replaced or ${key:format} which specifies a format function. keys are case-sensitive.

parameters.name: transform
parameters.summary: a function to process all parameters before substitution takes place, e.g. mylib.encodeXML

parameters.name: thisObject
parameters.summary: where to look for optional format function; default to the global namespace

methods.summary: Performs parameterized substitutions on a string. Throws an exception if any parameter is unmatched.
examples:
Substitutes two expressions in a string from an Array or Object 

// returns "File 'foo.html' is not found in directory '/temp'."
// by providing substitution data in an Array
string.substitute(
    "File '${0}' is not found in directory '${1}'.",
    ["foo.html","/temp"]
);

// also returns "File 'foo.html' is not found in directory '/temp'."
// but provides substitution data in an Object structure.  Dotted
// notation may be used to traverse the structure.
string.substitute(
    "File '${name}' is not found in directory '${info.dir}'.",
    { name: "foo.html", info: { dir: "/temp" } }
);

Use a transform function to modify the values: 

// returns "file 'foo.html' is not found in directory '/temp'."
string.substitute(
    "${0} is not found in ${1}.",
    ["foo.html","/temp"],
    function(str){
        // try to figure out the type
        var prefix = (str.charAt(0) == "/") ? "directory": "file";
        return prefix + " '" + str + "'";
    }
);

Use a formatter 

// returns "thinger -- howdy"
string.substitute(
    "${0:postfix}", ["thinger"], null, {
        postfix: function(value, key){
            return value + " -- howdy";
        }
    }
);

methods.name: trim
methods.summary: Trims whitespace from both sides of the string
methods.description: This version of trim() was taken from Steven Levithan's blog. The short yet performant version of this function is dojo/_base/lang.trim(), which is part of Dojo base. Uses String.prototype.trim instead, if available.
